posts.name: Mason
posts.cooked: I am the only experienced programmer on my team and I am having some difficulty teaching the other members how to program the robot. Is there recommended teaching strategies that I should employ or perhaps resources to aid in my teaching?

posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked: Get some Romi robots. About $300 and they can have a robot driving in a couple of hours. Same software interface as the roborio system so the coding is virtually the same. And that moves people from online tutorials (boring) to driving a robot around (fun).

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
We support both Romi and XRP.

The Romi is a small and inexpensive robot designed for learning about programming FRC robots. All the same tools used for programming full-sized FRC robots can be used to program the Romi. The Romi...

The XRP is a small and inexpensive robot designed for learning about programming FRC robots. All the same tools used for programming full-sized FRC robots can be used to program the XRP. The XRP co...

iirc, the XRP is cheaper.

link_counts.title: Getting Started with XRP — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
Getting Started with Romi — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Scarlett Saam
posts.cooked:
Definitely ease people into it, give them the general information and some easy projects. If you throw a whole robot at them they might get overwhelmed, so starting small is a good strategy. You could have sessions in which you explain how something works and then you put it in to practice in code and observe.

For starters, if you use Github, I recommend walking them through how it works so that they know how to add to projects. Then, they can practice making pulls/pushes/commits.

Make sure everyone knows the what bare bones of a robot project are and what they do (for us it’s subsystems, robot container, commands, robot, main, etc.)

You could make a super easy project for them to add on to, like show them some code that makes a motor move with the push of a button and as you teach them more they could add to the project (add more motors, more buttons, etc.)

There are SO MANY really awesome robotics people on Youtube who have really in-depth walkthroughs of robot code, so I recommend you check that out for ideas or even to show your software team so they get some good practice.

Me personally, I think iteration is really important for learning software, so go over things repeatedly so that they remember well.

The WPIlib docs are also a really good tool for explaining some niche topics in code, so use that too.

Honestly, a lot of this depends on where your software team is skill-wise. Maybe take an assessment of their skills and move from there?

Good luck!

It depends what you are having difficulty with. Do the newer members already know the basics of the language you code in and only need to learn how to program the bot, or do they not know how to code at all.

If they do not know how to code there are plenty of free online courses and materials which can help you.

If they do know how to code then I would try looking at materials from other teams. I am sure there are plenty of teams who post slideshows which they use to explain the basics of programming the robot. This should cover things like how to use subsystems and motors, the classes that are given when creating a new project (robot, constants, etc …), and the command base system if you use it.

After that decides what tasks they should start working on. The most effective learning is done hands on and it will only happen if they start doing things. Once you decide find some material to teach them what they need to know for that topic (not the actual thing but base knowledge. For example for someone to work on calculate angles for a shooter they will need some basic trigonometry) and let them dive in. You will still need to guide them but they should be doing most of the work and you add your feedback and teach them how to improve.

posts.custom_user_title: Alumni of LakerBots 8046 | Programming | On this forum too much

posts.cooked:
Have to really agree with what’s been said above about practical experience, and especially having something to see your code run on. It doesn’t have to be your competition robot if you have other robots - e.g. offseason bots or those from last year. Personally I’m new to FRC this year (though with significant experience programming beforehand) and seeing code that I wrote running on an actual real-life robot was great. That’s also why the Romi’s good - because you can program an actual robot.

Also, it’s important to approach those new to programming (and also those who have programmed before) with respect and understanding that they are still learning. Even though I am new this year, as I said above I have programming experience, and I think that my (more than) slightly abrasive behavior towards those looking to join the programming team but with less programming experience than I, for example in PR reviews on GitHub, may have contributed to said members being less involved.

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
apotato:

i wrote out some docs for introducing new students to wpilib and our codebase. while some of it is specific to my team some may be helpful, especially the kitbot code walkthrough. GitHub - HighlanderRobotics/Highlanders-Training: Training materials for FRC 8033

Remember that new programmers have to learn 4 new concepts.

Basic syntax and grammar of the programming language

How to algorithmically solve problems

How to design high level compositions and structure to algorithmically solve problems

Robots

The nice part about this guide is it covers all of these things in basics.

Simulation support is a big help, getting LED animations correct with the AddressableLED classes from WPILib are a nice challenge to give people creative freedom as to how to solve the logic and periodic nature of robots.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
On 2491 We like to start with the basics of Python on an adafruit Circuit Playground. They are like $20 each, have lots of things to play with on them, and overall are a nice intro without having to spend on something quite so expensive like a Romi (they are a great option though).  Feel free to use our online wiki which basically acts as a step by step:

Code and resources for learning Circuit Python. Contribute to 2491-NoMythic/circuitPython development by creating an account on GitHub.

After they complete the wiki we generally have them switch to our general Java course (Does NOT involve the robot yet) GitHub - 2491-NoMythic/JavaIntro: Java intro examples for those just learning Java

This is basically just a set of easy problems building their skills through the syntax, after learning how to think like a computer in the python course.

After completing this course we generally have them go into non command based robot programming on something really simple (think a drive train with an intake). Through this they learn how to run a motor in both directions, how to use a controller and a lot of the basics.

then we move them to command based code. We teach them the structure individually, and then redo the simple robot movement + intake again.

After that, its really up to them where they want to go. We have them learn all of this in the fall, then each student generally gets one simple subsystem to make their own. With the higher level programmers working on other things like vision, tying the systems together, autos ect.  The second year then starts with them programming a robot for something called “mini trials” basically a very short quickly built robot for a small local competition with a new game every year. Basically a mini FRC season. We try to have the 2nd year programmers take this on and really learn the ways of the robots. Then by the time the spring of their second year rolls around, they are truly ready to contribute in a meaningful way.

link_counts.title: GitHub - 2491-NoMythic/JavaIntro: Java intro examples for those just learning Java
